column1: Information : October 13
Information : The Third Kennedy-Nixon Presidential Debate
Bill Shadel : Good evening.
Bill Shadel : I'm Bill Shadel of ABC News.
Bill Shadel : It's my privilege this evening to preside at this the third in the series of meetings on radio and television of the two major presidential candidates.
Bill Shadel : Now like the last meeting the subjects to be discussed will be suggested by questions from a panel of correspondents.
Bill Shadel : Unlike the first two programs
column2: however
column3: the two candidates will not be sharing the same platform.

column1: Bill Shadel : In New York the Democratic presidential nominee
column2: Senator John F. Kennedy; separated by three thousand miles in a Los Angeles studio
column3: the Republican presidential nominee
column4: Vice President Richard M. Nixon; now joined for tonight's discussion by a network of electronic facilities which permits each candidate to see and hear the other.

column1: Bill Shadel : Good evening
column2: Senator Kennedy.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Good evening
column2: Mr. Shadel.

column1: Bill Shadel : And good evening to you
column2: Vice President Nixon.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Good evening
column2: Mr. Shadel.

column1: Bill Shadel : And now to meet the panel of correspondents.
Bill Shadel : Frank McGee
column2: NBC News; Charles Van Fremd
column3: CBS News; Douglass Cater
column4: Reporter magazine; Roscoe Drummond
column5: New York Herald Tribune.

column1: Bill Shadel : Now
column2: as you've probably noted
column3: the four reporters include a newspaper man and a magazine reporter; these two selected by lot by the press secretaries of the candidates from among the reporters traveling with the candidates.

column1: Bill Shadel : The broadcasting representatives were chosen by their companies.
Bill Shadel : The rules for this evening have been agreed upon by the representatives of both candidates and the radio and television networks and I should like to read them.
Bill Shadel : There will be no opening statements by the candidates nor any closing summation.
Bill Shadel : The entire hour will be devoted to answering questions from the reporters.
Bill Shadel : Each candidate to be questioned in turn with opportunity for comment by the other.
Bill Shadel : Each answer will be limited to two and one-half minutes
column2: each comment to one and a half minutes.

column1: Bill Shadel : The reporters are free to ask any question they choose on any subject.
Bill Shadel : Neither candidate knows what questions will be asked.
Bill Shadel : Time alone will dete- determine who will be asked the final question.
Bill Shadel : Now the first question is from Mr. McGee and is for Senator Kennedy.
Frank McGee : "Senator Kennedy
column2: yesterday you used the words ""trigger-happy"" in referring to Vice President Richard Nixon's stand on defending the islands of Quemoy and Matsu."

column1: Frank McGee : Last week on a program like this one
column2: you said the next president would come face to face with a serious crisis in Berlin.

column1: Frank McGee : So the question is: would you take military action to defend Berlin?
John F. Kennedy : Mr. McGee
column2: we have a contractual right to be in Berlin coming out of the conversations at Potsdam and of World War II.

column1: John F. Kennedy : That has been reinforced by direct commitments of the president of the United States; it's been reinforced by a number of other nations under NATO.
John F. Kennedy : I've stated on many occasions that the United States must meet its commitment on Berlin.
John F. Kennedy : It is a commitment that we have to meet if we're going to protect the security of Western Europe.

John F. Kennedy : And therefore on this question I don't think that there is any doubt in the mind of any American; I hope there is not any doubt in the mind of any member of the community of West Berlin; I'm sure there isn't any doubt in the mind of the Russians.
John F. Kennedy : We will meet our commitments to maintain the freedom and independence of West Berlin.
Bill Shadel : Mr. Vice President
column2: do you wish to comment?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Yes.
Richard M. Nixon : As a matter of fact
column2: the statement that Senator Kennedy made was that - to the effect that there were trigger-happy Republicans
column3: that my stand on Quemoy and Matsu was an indication of trigger-happy Republicans.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I resent that comment.
Richard M. Nixon : I resent it because th- it's an implication that Republicans have been trigger-happy and
column2: therefore
column3: would lead this nation into war.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I would remind Senator Kennedy of the past fifty years.
Richard M. Nixon : I would ask him to name one Republican president who led this nation into war.
Richard M. Nixon : There were three Democratic presidents who led us into war.
Richard M. Nixon : I do not mean by that that one party is a war party and the other party is a peace party.
Richard M. Nixon : But I do say that any statement to the effect that the Republican party is trigger-happy is belied by the record.
Richard M. Nixon : We had a war when we came into power in 1953.
Richard M. Nixon : We got rid of that; we've kept out of other wars; and certainly that doesn't indicate that we're trigger-happy.
Richard M. Nixon : We've been strong
column2: but we haven't been trigger-happy.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : As far as Berlin is concerned
column2: there isn't any question about the necessity of defending Berlin; the rights of people there to be free; and there isn't any question about what the united American people - Republicans and Democrats alike - would do in the event there were an attempt by the Communists to take over Berlin.

column1: Bill Shadel : The next question is by Mr.
Bill Shadel : Von Fremd for Vice President Nixon.
Charles Van Fremd : Mr. Vice President
column2: a two-part question concerning the offshore islands in the Formosa Straits.

column1: Charles Van Fremd : If you were president and the Chinese Communists tomorrow began an invasion of Quemoy and Matsu
column2: would you launch the uh - United States into a war by sending the Seventh Fleet and other military forces to resist this aggression; and secondly
column3: if the uh - regular conventional forces failed to halt such uh - such an invasion
column4: would you authorize the use of nuclear weapons?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Mr.
Richard M. Nixon : Von Fremd
column2: it would be completely irresponsible for a candidate for the presidency
column3: or for a president himself
column4: to indicate the course of action and the weapons he would use in the event of such an attack.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I will say this: in the event that such an attack occurred and in the event the attack was a prelude to an attack on Formosa - which would be the indication today because the Chinese Communists say over and over again that their objective is not the offshore islands
column2: that they consider them only steppingstones to taking Formosa - in the event that their attack then were a prelude to an attack on Formosa
column3: there isn't any question but that the United States would then again
column4: as in the case of Berlin
column5: honor our treaty obligations and stand by our ally of Formosa.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : But to indicate in advance how we would respond
column2: to indicate the nature of this response would be incorrect; it would certainly be inappropriate; it would not be in the best interests of the United States.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I will only say this
column2: however
column3: in addition: to do what Senator Kennedy has suggested - to suggest that we will surrender these islands or force our Chinese Nationalist allies to surrender them in advance - is not something that would lead to peace; it is something that would lead
column4: in my opinion
column5: to war.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : This is the history of dealing with dictators.
Richard M. Nixon : This is something that Senator Kennedy and all Americans must know.
Richard M. Nixon : We tried this with Hitler.
Richard M. Nixon : It didn't work.
Richard M. Nixon : He wanted first uh - we know
column2: Austria
column3: and then he went on to the Sudetenland and then Danzig
column4: and each time it was thought this is all that he wanted.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Now what do the Chinese Communists want?
Richard M. Nixon : They don't want just Quemoy and Matsu; they don't want just Formosa; they want the world.
Richard M. Nixon : And the question is if you surrender or indicate in advance that you're not going to defend any part of the free world
column2: and you figure that's going to satisfy them
column3: it doesn't satisfy them.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : It only whets their appetite; and then the question comes
column2: when do you stop them?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I've often heard President Eisenhower in discussing this question
column2: make the statement that if we once start the process of indicating that this point or that point is not the place to stop those who threaten the peace and freedom of the world
column3: where do we stop them?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And I say that those of us who stand against surrender of territory - this or any others - in the face of blackmail
column2: in the s- face of force by the Communists are standing for the course that will lead to peace.

column1: Bill Shadel : Senator Kennedy
column2: do you wish to comment?

column1: John F. Kennedy : Yes.
John F. Kennedy : The whole th- the United States now has a treaty - which I voted for in the United States Senate in 1955 - to defend Formosa and the Pescadores Island.
John F. Kennedy : The islands which Mr. Nixon is discussing are five or four miles
column2: respectively
column3: off the coast of China.

column1: John F. Kennedy : "Now when Senator Green
column2: the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column3: wrote to the President
column4: he received back on the second of October
column5: 1958 - ""neither you nor any other American need feel the U.S. will be involved in military hostilities merely in the defense of Quemoy and Matsu."""

column1: John F. Kennedy : Now
column2: that is the issue.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I believe we must meet our commitment to uh - Formosa.
John F. Kennedy : I support it and the Pescadores Island.
John F. Kennedy : That is the present American position.
John F. Kennedy : The treaty does not include these two islands.
John F. Kennedy : Mr. Nixon suggests uh - that the United States should go to war if these two islands are attacked.
John F. Kennedy : I suggest that if Formosa is attacked or the Pescadores
column2: or if there's any military action in any area which indicates an attack on Formosa and the Pescadores
column3: then of course the United States is at war to defend its treaty.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Now
column2: I must say what Mr. Nixon wants to do is commit us - as I understand him
column3: so that we can be clear if there's a disagreement - he wants us to be committed to the defense of these islands merely as the defense of these islands as free territory
column4: not as part of the defense of Formosa.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Admiral Yarnell
column2: the commander of the Asiatic fleet
column3: has said that these islands are not worth the bones of a single American.

column1: John F. Kennedy : The President of the United States has indicated they are not within the treaty area.
John F. Kennedy : They were not within the treaty area when the treaty was passed in fifty-five.
John F. Kennedy : We have attempted to persuade Chiang Kai-shek as late as January of 1959 to reduce the number of troops he has on them.
John F. Kennedy : This is a serious issue
column2: and I think we ought to understand completely if we disagree
column3: and if so
column4: where.

column1: Bill Shadel : Mr. Cater has the next question for Senator Kennedy.
Douglass Cater : Senator Kennedy
column2: last week you said that before we should hold another summit conference
column3: that it was important that the United States build its strength.

column1: Douglass Cater : Modern weapons take quite a long time to build.
Douglass Cater : What sort of prolonged period do you envisage before there can be a summit conference?
Douglass Cater : And do you think that there can be any new initiatives on the grounds of nuclear disarmament uh - nuclear control or weapons control d- uh - during this period?
John F. Kennedy : Well I think we should st- strengthen our conventional forces
column2: and we should attempt in January
column3: February
column4: and March of next year to increase the airlift capacity of our conventional forces.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Then I believe that we should move full time on our missile production
column2: particularly on Minuteman and on Polaris.

column1: John F. Kennedy : It may be a long period
column2: but we must - we must get started immediately.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Now on the question of disarmament
column2: particularly nuclear disarmament
column3: I must say that I feel that another effort should be made by a new Administration in January of 1961
column4: to renew negotiations with the Soviet Union and see whether it's possible to come to some conclusion which will lessen the chances of contamination of the atmosphere
column5: and also lessen the chances that other powers will begin to possess a nuclear capacity.

column1: John F. Kennedy : There are indications
column2: because of new inventions
column3: that ten
column4: fifteen
column5: or twenty nations will have a nuclear capacity - including Red China - by the end of the presidential office in 1964.

column1: John F. Kennedy : This is extremely serious.
John F. Kennedy : There have been many wars in the history of mankind.
John F. Kennedy : And to take a chance uh - now be - and not make every effort that we could make to provide for some control over these weapons
column2: I think would be a great mistake.

column1: John F. Kennedy : One of my disagreements with the present Administration has been that I don't feel a real effort has been made an this very sensitive subject
column2: not only of nuclear controls
column3: but also of general disarmament.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Less than a hundred people have been working throughout the entire federal government on this subject
column2: and I believe it's been reflected in our success and failures at Geneva.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Now
column2: we may not succeed.

column1: John F. Kennedy : The Soviet Union may not agree to an inspection system.
John F. Kennedy : We may be able to get satisfactory assurances.
John F. Kennedy : It may be necessary for us to begin testing again.
John F. Kennedy : But I hope the next Administration - and if I have anything to do with it
column2: the next Administration will - make one last great effort to provide for control of nuclear testing
column3: control of nuclear weapons
column4: if possible
column5: control of outer space
column7: and also to begin again the subject of general disarmament levels.

column1: John F. Kennedy : These must be done.
John F. Kennedy : If we cannot succeed
column2: then we must strengthen ourselves.

column1: John F. Kennedy : But I would make the effort because I think the fate not only of our own civilization
column2: but I think the fate of world and the future of the human race is involved in preventing a nuclear war.

column1: Bill Shadel : Mr. Vice President
column2: your comment?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Yes.
Richard M. Nixon : I am going to make a major speech on this whole subject next week before the next debate
column2: and I will have an opportunity then to answer any other questions that may arise with regard to my position on it.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : There isn't any question but that we must move forward in every possible way to reduce the danger of war; to move toward controlled disarmament; to control tests; but also let's have in mind this: when Senator Kennedy suggests that we haven't been making an effort
column2: he simply doesn't know what he's talking about.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : It isn't a question of the number of people who are working in an Administration.
Richard M. Nixon : It's a question of who they are.
Richard M. Nixon : This has been one of the highest level operations in the whole State Department right under the President himself.
Richard M. Nixon : We have gone certainly the extra mile and then some in making offers to the Soviet Union on control of tests
column2: on disarmament
column3: and in every other way.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And I just want to make one thing very clear.
Richard M. Nixon : Yes
column2: we should make a great effort.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : But under no circumstances must the United States ever make an agreement based on trust.
Richard M. Nixon : There must be an absolute guarantee.
Richard M. Nixon : Now
column2: just a comment on Senator Kennedy's last answer.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : He forgets that in this same debate on the Formosa resolution
column2: which he said he voted for - which he did - that he voted against an amendment
column3: or was recorded against an amendment - and on this particular - or for an amendment
column4: I should say - which passed the Senate overwhelmingly
column5: seventy to twelve.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And that amendment put the Senate of the United States on record with a majority of the Senator's own party voting for it
column2: as well as the majority of Republicans - put them on record - against the very position that the Senator takes now of surrendering
column3: of indicating in advance
column4: that the United States will not defend the offshore islands.

column1: Bill Shadel : The next question is by Mr. Drummond for Vice President Nixon.
Roscoe Drummond : Mr. Nixon
column2: I would like to ask eh - one more aspect or raise another aspect of this same question.

column1: Roscoe Drummond : Uh - it is my understanding that President Eisenhower never advocated that Quemoy and Matsu should be defended under all circumstances as a matter of principle.
Roscoe Drummond : I heard Secretary Dulles at a press conference in fifty-eight say that he thought that it was a mistake for Chiang Kai-shek to deploy troops to these islands.
Roscoe Drummond : I would like to ask what has led you to take what appears to be a different position on this subject.
Richard M. Nixon : Well Mr. Drummond
column2: first of all
column3: referring to Secretary Dulles' press conference
column4: I think if you read it all - and I know that you have - you will find that Secretary Dulles also indicated in that press conference that when the troops were withdrawn from Quemoy
column5: that the implication was certainly of everything that he said
column6: that Quemoy could better be defended.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : There were too many infantrymen there
column2: not enough heavy artillery; and certainly I don't think there was any implication in Secretary Dulles' statement that Quemoy and Matsu should not be defended in the event that they were attacked
column3: and that attack was a preliminary to an attack on Formosa.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Now as far as President Eisenhower is concerned
column2: I have often heard him discuss this question.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : As I uh - related a moment ago
column2: the President has always indicated that we must not make the mistake in dealing with the dictator of indicating that we are going to make a concession at the point of a gun.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Whenever you do that
column2: inevitably the dictator is encouraged to try it again.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : So first it will be Quemoy and Matsu
column2: next it may be Formosa.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : What do we do then?
Richard M. Nixon : My point is this: that once you do this - follow this course of action - of indicating that you are not going to defend a particular area
column2: the inevitable result is that it encourages a man who is determined to conquer the world to press you to the point of no return.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And that means war.
Richard M. Nixon : We went through this tragic experience leading to World War II.
Richard M. Nixon : We learned our lesson again in Korea
column2: We must not learn it again.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : That is why I think the Senate was right
column2: including a majority of the Democrats
column3: a majority of the Republicans
column4: when they rejected Senator Kennedy's position in 1955.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And incidentally
column2: Senator Johnson was among those who rejected that position - voted with the seventy against the twelve.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : The Senate was right because they knew the lesson of history.
Richard M. Nixon : And may I say
column2: too
column3: that I would trust that Senator Kennedy would change his position on this - change it; because as long as he as a major presidential candidate continues to suggest that we are going to turn over these islands
column4: he is only encouraging the aggressors - the Chinese Communist and the Soviet aggressors - to press the United States
column5: to press us to the point where war would be inevitable.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : The road to war is always paved with good intentions.
Richard M. Nixon : And in this instance the good intentions
column2: of course
column3: are a desire for peace.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : But certainly we're not going to have peace by giving in and indicating in advance that we are not going to defend what has become a symbol of freedom.
Bill Shadel : Senator Kennedy.
John F. Kennedy : I don't think it's possible for Mr. Nixon to state the record in distortion of the facts with more precision than he just did.
John F. Kennedy : "In 1955
column2: Mr. Dulles at a press conference said: ""The treaty that we have with the Republic of China excludes Quemoy and Matsu from the treaty area."""

column1: John F. Kennedy : That was done with much thought and deliberation.
John F. Kennedy : Therefore that treaty does not commit the United States to defend anything except Formosa and the Pescadores
column2: and to deal with acts against that treaty area.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I completely sustained the treaty.
John F. Kennedy : I voted for it.
John F. Kennedy : I would take any action necessary to defend the treaty
column2: Formosa
column3: and the Pescadores Island.

column1: John F. Kennedy : What we're now talking about is the Vice President's determination to guarantee Quemoy and Matsu
column2: which are four and five miles off the coast of Red China
column3: which are not within the treaty area.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I do not suggest that Chiang Kai-shek - and this Administration has been attempting since 1955 to persuade Chiang Kai-shek to lessen his troop commitments.
John F. Kennedy : Uh - He sent a mission - the President - in 1955 of Mr. uh - Robertson and Admiral Radford.
John F. Kennedy : General Twining said they were still doing it in 1959.
John F. Kennedy : "General Ridgway said - who was Chief of Staff: ""To go to war for Quemoy and Matsu to me would seem an unwarranted and tragic course to take."
John F. Kennedy : "To me that concept is completely repugnant."""
John F. Kennedy : So I stand with them.
John F. Kennedy : I stand with the Secretary of State
column2: Mr. Herter
column3: who said these islands were indefensible.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I believe that we should meet our commitments
column2: and if the Chinese Communists attack the Pescadores and Formosa
column3: they know that it will mean a war.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I would not ho- hand over these islands under any point of gun.
John F. Kennedy : But I merely say that the treaty is quite precise and I sustain the treaty.
John F. Kennedy : Mr. Nixon would add a guarantee to islands five miles off the coast of the re- Republic of China when he's never really protested the Communists seizing Cuba
column2: ninety miles off the coast of the United States.

column1: Bill Shadel : Mr.
Bill Shadel : Von Fremd has a question for Senator Kennedy.
Charles Van Fremd : Senator Kennedy
column2: I'd like to uh - shift the conversation
column3: if I may
column4: to a domestic uh - political argument.

column1: Charles Van Fremd : The chairman of the Republican National Committee
column2: Senator Thruston Morton
column3: declared earlier this week that you owed Vice President Nixon and the Republican party a public apology for some strong charges made by former President Harry Truman
column4: who bluntly suggested where the Vice President and the Republican party could go.

column1: Charles Van Fremd : Do you feel that you owe the Vice President an apology?
John F. Kennedy : Well
column2: I must say that uh - Mr. Truman has uh - his methods of expressing things; he's been in politics for fifty years; he's been president of the United States.

column1: John F. Kennedy : They may - are not my style.
John F. Kennedy : But I really don't think there's anything that I could say to President Truman that's going to cause him
column2: at the age of seventy-six
column3: to change his particular speaking manner.

column1: John F. Kennedy : Perhaps Mrs. Truman can
column2: but I don't think I can.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I'll just have to tell Mr. Morton that.
John F. Kennedy : If you'd pass that message on to him.
Bill Shadel : Any comment
column2: Mr. Vice President?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Yes
column2: I think so.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Of course
column2: both er - Senator Kennedy and I have felt Mr. Truman's ire; and uh - consequently
column3: I think he can speak with some feeling on this subject.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I just do want to say one thing
column2: however.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : We all have tempers; I have one; I'm sure Senator Kennedy has one.
Richard M. Nixon : But when a man's president of the United States
column2: or a former president
column3: he has an obligation not to lose his temper in public.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : One thing I've noted as I've traveled around the country are the tremendous number of children who come out to see the presidential candidates.
Richard M. Nixon : I see mothers holding their babies up
column2: so that they can see a man who might be president of the United States.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I know Senator Kennedy sees them
column2: too.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : It makes you realize that whoever is president is going to be a man that all the children of America will either look up to
column2: or will look down to.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And I can only say that I'm very proud that President Eisenhower restored dignity and decency and
column2: frankly
column3: good language to the conduct of the presidency of the United States.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : "And I only hope that
column2: should I win this election
column3: that I could approach President Eisenhower in maintaining the dignity of the office; in seeing to it that whenever any mother or father talks to his child
column4: he can look at the man in the White House and
column5: whatever he may think of his policies
column7: there is a man who maintains the kind of standards personally that I would want my child to follow."""

column1: Bill Shadel : Mr. Cater's question is for Vice President Nixon.
Douglass Cater : Mr. Vice President
column2: I'd like to return just once more
column3: if I may
column4: to this area of dealing with the Communists.

column1: Douglass Cater : Critics have claimed that on at least three occasions in recent years - on the sending of American troops to Indochina in 1954
column2: on the matter of continuing the U-2 flights uh - in May
column3: and then on this definition of the - of our commitment to the offshore island - that you have overstated the Administration position
column4: that you have taken a more bellicose position than President Eisenhower.

column1: Douglass Cater : Just two days ago you said that you called on uh - Senator Kennedy to serve notice to Communist aggressors around the world that we're not going to retreat one inch more any place
column2: where as we did retreat from the Tachen Islands
column3: or at least Chiang Kai-shek did.

column1: Douglass Cater : Would you say this was a valid criticism of your statement of foreign policy?
Richard M. Nixon : Well
column2: Mr. Cater
column3: of course it's a criticism that uh - is being made.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Uh - I obviously don't think it's valid.
Richard M. Nixon : I have supported the Administration's position and I think that that position has been correct; I think my position has been correct.
Richard M. Nixon : As far as Indochina was concerned
column2: I stated over and over again that it was essential during that period that the United States make it clear that we would not tolerate Indochina falling under Communist domination.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Now
column2: as a result of our taking the strong stand that we did
column3: the civil war there was ended; and today
column4: at least in the south of Indochina
column5: the Communists have moved out and we do have a strong

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Now
column2: looking to the U-2 flights
column3: I would like to point out that I have been supporting the President's position throughout.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I think the President was correct in ordering these flights.
Richard M. Nixon : I think the President was correct
column2: certainly
column3: in his decision to continue the flights while the conference was going on.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : I noted
column2: for example
column3: in reading a - uh - a - a particular discussion that Senator Kennedy had with Dave Garroway shortly after the uh - his statement about regrets
column4: that uh - he made the statement that he felt that these particular flights uh - were ones that shouldn't have occurred right at that time
column5: and the indication was how would Mr. Khrushchev had felt if we had uh - had a flight over the uni- how would we have felt if Mr. Khrushchev ha - uh - had a flight over the United States while uh - he was visiting here.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : And the answer
column2: of course
column3: is that Communist espionage goes on all the time.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : The answer is that the United States can't afford to have a es- an es - a espionage lack or should we s- uh - lag - or should I say uh - an intelligence lag - any more than we can afford to have a missile lag.
Richard M. Nixon : Now
column2: referring to your question with regard to Quemoy and Matsu.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : What I object to here is the constant reference to surrendering these islands.
Richard M. Nixon : Senator Kennedy quotes the record
column2: which he read from a moment ago
column3: but what he forgets to point out is that the key vote - a uh - vote which I've referred to several times - where he was in the minority was one which rejected his position.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Now
column2: why did they reject it?

column1: Richard M. Nixon : For the very reason that those Senators knew
column2: as the President of the United States knew
column3: that you should not indicate to the Communists in advance that you're going to surrender an area that's free.

column1: Richard M. Nixon : Why?
Richard M. Nixon : Because they know as Senator Kennedy will have to know that if you do that you encourage them to more aggression.
Bill Shadel : Senator Kennedy?
John F. Kennedy : "Well number one on Indochina
column2: Mr. Nixon talked in - before the newspaper editors in the spring of 1954 about putting
column3: and I quote him
column4: ""American boys into Indochina."""

column1: John F. Kennedy : The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina.
John F. Kennedy : Number two
column2: on the question of the U-2 flights.

column1: John F. Kennedy : I thought the.
John F. Kennedy : U-2 flight in May just before the conference was a mistake in timing because of the hazards involved
